title: The Healing Power of Nature

content: In my opinion, healing comes in many forms.
There’s healing where you are totally and completely cured of whatever it is that ails you. Diseases go away and pain is made right. Physically, you’re whole again.
Healing also happens when your heart is mended after being broken, and the pain you felt is replaced with new hope, love, and light.

The type of healing I most associate with is the one where you receive the strength to continue in the face of hardships. It’s not a “full” healing in that what you’re struggling with disappears, but it’s a healing nonetheless.

Recently, during a trying time, I found myself standing on the beach. Everywhere I looked there was activity: families playing in the water, seagulls swooping all around in hopes of catching a tasty meal, and boats lingering out in the distance.

Yet as I stood there, staring out at the endless expanse, every other sound seemed to fade away. Drowned out by the roar of the ocean waves crashing repeatedly on the shore, I started to feel as if I were the only person there. Just me and the ocean.

content: As I watched the waves build, crash, pull back, and then do it all over again, the turmoil inside me seemed to quiet as well. For the first time in a while, I was content to just stand there with my thoughts. And the longer I stood there, the more I realized that maybe, just maybe, things weren’t quite as bad as they seemed.

I didn’t want to leave. My problems weren’t gone and my mental health wasn’t suddenly cured from any struggle, but the depression I felt about the situation lifted just a bit. The anxiety that was ever present suddenly didn’t feel as ominous, and I didn’t have the desire to just get away from it at all costs.

I walked away from the beach that day with a new perspective, one that carried me through the ups and downs of that time in my life. The experience I had that day and the healing that accompanied it gave me that little bit of light and hope that I needed to keep going.

content: As time has gone on, I’ve realized that I don’t have to be at the beach to find that same peace and healing. It’s in nature all around us, no matter what that looks like.

I’ve felt it walking in the mountains, breathing in the scent of pine trees, and letting the sun warm my face. I’ve felt it sitting near the river, watching the water steadily move downstream, heedless of the branches and rocks in its path.
When times get hard, when depression and anxiety are all-consuming and I feel it’s all I can do to just keep my head above water, so to speak, I remind myself of the healing nature offers.
It won’t take my struggles away, but it will give me a brief respite. It will offer me perspective and show me that life is full of ups and downs, struggles and successes, good times and bad.
It will give me the strength I need to keep going, helping me to realize that everything changes, and the way I feel in hard moments will change too.
